bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dorothy Epstein (1913-2006) was a labor, political and community activist and organizer. She worked at the New York City Department of Welfare where she organized the first sit-down strike and later became the first female local president in the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Eemployees, District Council 37. She was also involved in the Russian War Relief, American Labor Party, and Hunter College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the following: labor and political pamphlets (1920-1950); an International Ladies' Garment Workers Uunion souvenir apron; political buttons (Spanish Civil War - present); photograph and ephemera scrapbooks, respectively, for the American Jewish Labor Council (1940s) and the American Labor Party (1940s); correspondence from William Levner; a National Citizens PAC and New York CIO Council organizing manual, flyers, reports, souvenir programs; Bronx Council, Emma Lazarus Clubs (1960s -1970s); United Public Workers membership cards and reports (early 1940s); miscellaneous letters, certificates, and other material relating to Epstein's mother, Sophie Epstein; and an "Angela Davis Must Be Free!" record.
